docs.lead_paragraph: In an orchestrated display of party muscle and unity, all but one of the nation's Republican governors descended on the Texas capital today, vowing to wage a relentless fight to propel one of their own into the White House. At a midafternoon rally for Gov. George W. Bush that kicked off three days of barnstorming across 25 battleground states, the 28 governors stood on a three-tiered stage, laughing as they found their assigned places marked on the floor with tape. It was a gathering intended to reinforce Mr. Bush's theme that he represented a more pragmatic style of leadership distinct from the partisanship of Washington.
docs.abstract: Twenty-eight Republican governors rally in Austin, Tex, with Gov George W Bush in orchestrated display of party muscle, vowing to wage relentless fight to propel him into White House; will barnstorm across 25 battleground states over next three days as part of campaign effort; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: CAMPAIGN COMPLAINT Seeking to highlight what they say are Hillary Rodham Clinton's unethical fund-raising practices, Republican officials in New York have filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission over Mrs. Clinton's use of an official White House list for fund-raising solicitations. Mrs. Clinton acknowledged this month that 1,400 names from an official invitation list for a White House holiday party had been sent to her campaign and put on fund-raising lists. She said that the use of the list was an accident and that no wrongdoing had occurred. Her Senate campaign on Friday called the complaint a political stunt. Clifford J. Levy (NYT) ALBANY: MINORITY POLICE RECRUITMENT The New York State Police Academy is having difficulty recruiting women and members of minority groups. In the class of 84 troopers that graduated last week, four were women, three were black and one was Hispanic. The seven-month gap between taking the police examination and entering the academy is a major factor, said Col. Harry J. Corbitt, deputy superintendent at the academy. ''A lot can happen in seven months when you're in your mid-20's,'' the age of many applicants, he said. For example, in the most recent class, of the 149 women the academy admitted, six entered and four graduated. (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: In his campaign for Senate, Representative Rick A. Lazio has portrayed himself as a can-do sort of politician: effective because he is part of the House Republican majority, but sufficiently independent to defy his party when New York's interests are at stake. ''I think we need somebody in the majority party,'' Mr. Lazio said in a recent debate with his Democratic rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton, ''who can work well with others, who can cross party lines, who can be independent, and who's got the ability to make sure that New York gets its fair share.''

headline.main: TIES THAT BIND: A special report.; Lazio's G.O.P. Role Is a Campaign Asset But Also a Liability

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A letter in your Q & A column on Sept. 10 asked about medical insurance abroad for travelers. Those concerned about health care options overseas may be interested in an organization called the International Association for Medical Assistance to Travelers, which provides a free directory that lists 500 medical centers in more than 100 countries.
